newsitem.title: UK: Alcan calls on EU to remove aluminium duty.
newsitem.headline: Alcan calls on EU to remove aluminium duty.

text.p: The European Union should immediately suspend its six percent tariff on aluminium ingot, a senior official of Alcan Aluminium Limited said in a speech prepared for delivery at a Financial Times/CRU Aluminium conference on Monday.
"The EU six percent tariff is illogical, discriminatory and distorts trade," said Jean-Pierre Ergas, Alcan Executive Vice-President with responsibility for European operations.

"It restricts access to global world class suppliers, taxes the EU semi-fabricating industry, distorts the economics of the aluminium industries in Europe and increases the prices paid by consumers of aluminium products. The EU should immediately suspend the duty on aluminium," Ergas added.
The EU was a net importer of unwrought aluminium, with annual imports of 2.7 million tonnes accounting for 56 percent of consumption, he said.
Imports could increase to 4.5 million tonnes over the next decade, while EU annual production capacity of some 2.3 million tonnes was unlikely to expand substantially.
The U.S. and Japan had no duties on imports of primary aluminium, he added.

"The main effect of the six percent tariff is to enable producers, including EU producers, to charge a premium irrespective of whether duty is actually payable, and as a result aluminium products in Europe suffer a higher material cost than in other parts of the world," he said.
In 1995 the downstream sector faced a cost disadvantage of over $470 million in the purchase of primary aluminium, $300 million of which was not paid as a duty but retained by smelters, he added.
